Implement IDisposable on 'AnalyisServicesRoleManager' because it creates members of the following IDisposable types: 'Server'. If 'AnalyisServicesRoleManager' has previously shipped, adding new members that implement IDisposable to this type is considered a breaking change to existing consumers.

Field 'AnalyisServicesRoleManager._Cube' is a member of type 'AnalyisServicesRoleManager', which is serializable, but is of type 'Cube', which is not serializable. Add the NonSerializedAttribute to 'AnalyisServicesRoleManager._Cube'.

Field 'AnalyisServicesRoleManager._DB' is a member of type 'AnalyisServicesRoleManager', which is serializable, but is of type 'Database', which is not serializable. Add the NonSerializedAttribute to 'AnalyisServicesRoleManager._DB'.

Field 'AnalyisServicesRoleManager._SSAS' is a member of type 'AnalyisServicesRoleManager', which is serializable, but is of type 'Server', which is not serializable. Add the NonSerializedAttribute to 'AnalyisServicesRoleManager._SSAS'.

Message.TypeName: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Message.Issue: The query string passed to 'SqlCommand.SqlCommand(string, SqlConnection)' in 'AnalyisServicesRoleManager.ExecuteStoredProcedure(string, string)' could contain the following variables 'sqlProcedureName'. If any of these variables could come from user input, consider using a stored procedure or a parameterized SQL query instead of building the query with string concatenations.

Message.Issue: The query string passed to 'SqlCommand.SqlCommand(string, SqlConnection)' in 'AnalyisServicesRoleManager.ExecuteStoredProcedure(string, string, string[], object[])' could contain the following variables 'sqlProcedureName'. If any of these variables could come from user input, consider using a stored procedure or a parameterized SQL query instead of building the query with string concatenations.

Rule.TypeName: Do not dispose objects multiple times
Rule.Name: Do not dispose objects multiple times
Rule.Description: A correctly implemented Dispose method can be called multiple times without throwing an exception. However, this is not guaranteed and to avoid generating a System.ObjectDisposedException you should not call Dispose more than one time on an object.
Rule.Resolution: Object {0} can be disposed more than once in method {1}. To avoid generating a System.ObjectDisposedException you should not call Dispose more than one time on an object.: Lines: 40

Rule.Name: Do not call overridable methods in constructors
Rule.Description: Virtual methods defined on the class should not be called from constructors. If a derived class has overridden the method, the derived class version will be called (before the derived class constructor is called).
Rule.Resolution: {0} contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences: {1}

Rule.Name: Implement ISerializable correctly
Rule.Description: If a type is assignable to ISerializable, it should implement GetObjectData. For unsealed types, the GetObjectData method should be callable and overridable by derived types.
Rule.Resolution: Add an implementation of GetObjectData to type {0}.

Rule.Name: Mark all non-serializable fields
Rule.Description: All fields that cannot be serialized directly should have the NonSerializedAttribute. Types that have the SerializableAttribute should not have fields of types that do not have the SerializableAttribute unless the fields are marked with the NonSerializedAttribute.
Rule.Resolution: Field {0} is a member of type {1}, which is serializable, but is of type {2}, which is not serializable. Add the NonSerializedAttribute to {0}.

Rule.Name: Mark ISerializable types with SerializableAttribute
Rule.Description: The System.Runtime.Serialization.ISerializable interface allows the type to customize its serialization, while the Serializable attribute enables the runtime to recognize the type as being serializable.
Rule.Resolution: Add [Serializable] to {0} as this type implements ISerializable.

Rule.TypeName: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Rule.Name: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Rule.Description: A SQL command string built from user input is vulnerable to SQL injection attacks. Microsoft SQL Server and other database servers support stored procedures and parameterized SQL queries, which reduce the risk of injection attacks.
Rule.Resolution: The query string passed to {0} in {1} could contain the following variables {2}. If any of these variables could come from user input, consider using a stored procedure or a parameterized SQL query instead of building the query with string concatenations.

Rule.Name: Types that own disposable fields should be disposable
Rule.Description: Types that declare disposable members should also implement IDisposable. If the type does not own any unmanaged resources, do not implement a finalizer on it.
Rule.Resolution: Implement IDisposable on {0} because it creates members of the following IDisposable types: {1}. If {0} has previously shipped, adding new members that implement IDisposable to this type is considered a breaking change to existing consumers.
